did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: Edward C. Blomeyer photographic collection

physdesc.extent: Over 1,500 photographic materials including Texas, Missouri, Illinois, Arkansas, North Carolina, Colorado, and Canada. The images were taken from approximately 1906-1923.

did.abstract: The Edward C. Blomeyer photographic collection contains photos from circa 1906 to 1923, including of the early telephone industry in Missouri and Texas, locations in Waco, and events such as the Texas Cotton Palace exhibition and parade. Blomeyer was president of the Texas Telephone Company.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Edward Charles (E.C) Blomeyer was born in Missouri in 1882. He married Amma Pottinger in 1904 and together they had three children, Mary, Edward, and Earle. During his time in Waco, Texas, 1912-1920, Mr. Blowmeyer became one of the early pioneers in the telephone industry in central Texas. He served in many capacities in this growing field, helping to establish and improve communication networks throughout the central Texas area. As well as his work in the telephone industry, he was active in community service in the Waco area. Examples include membership in the following organizations: the Young Men's Business League (YMBL), in which he served as chairman, Waco Chamber of Commerce, Waco Ad Club, Waco Public Library, and the Waco Rotary Club. He was also a member of the Karem Temple and various Masonic organizations in the city. Additionally, his two sons were born in Waco.

In 1904, Blomeyer entered the telephone industry working for the Southeast Missouri Telephone Company, in Charleston, Missouri, starting as auditor, then secretary, and later its manager. In 1912, he moved to Waco, Texas, to work for the Brazos Valley Telegraph and Telephone Company. In 1914, the Texas Telephone Company merged with 5 separate telephone companies in central, south, and east Texas. This conglomeration expanded the Texas Telephone Company greatly operating lines through thirty-four towns in the state at that time.

Blomeyer first served as secretary-treasurer of the newly formed Texas Telephone Company, as well as assistant to the president, J.B. (John Baylis) Earle II. The Texas Telephone Company's local expansion included Lorena, Mart, McGregor, Moody, Waco, and West, Texas. In 1918, E.C. Blomeyer became president of the TTC as the company continued to buy out or merge with several other independent telephone operations in the greater central Texas area. Additionally, in 1918, he began serving as president of the Texas Independent Telephone Association, a position he held until 1920; he would later be designated an honorary life member. Serving in this capacity he took part in proceedings, and later, executive positions in the United States Independent Telephone Association.

E.C. Blomeyer's time in Waco and the central Texas area helped build on his previous experience in the telephone industry. As a result, in 1920, he took a position with the Automatic Electric Company, owned by Theodore Gary and Co., of Chicago, Illinois. The AEC of Chicago's corporate lineage began in the Strowger Automatic Telephone Exchange Co., started by the inventor of the dial telephone, Almon Strowger. AEC bought the patents from Strowger in 1918 and was a major supplier of dial-telephones to independent telephone companies in the United States and abroad. Blomeyer's arrival at Automatic Electric was at an important time in that company's history. The Strowger (rotary-dial telephone) patents which they held had just been licensed to the Bell Corporation for a sum of $2.5 million. After the sale, AEC still continued to produce the rotary-dial system for telephone operations other than the Bell Corporation.

In his position at the Automatic Electric Company, Blomeyer also served as contract sales manager for its associated company, the International Telephone Sales and Engineering Corporation. In doing so, he supervised overseas business and contract sales of dial telephones. At this time, the AEC manufactured and supplied approximately 80 percent of the automatic dial-operated telephone equipment used worldwide. In 1923, he was made vice-president of Theodore Gary and Co., owner of the AEC, and remained so until his retirement in 1956. The Theodore Gary & Co., was later purchased by General Telephone Corporation in 1955, later renamed General Telephone & Electronics (GTE).

After retirement, he spent some of his remaining years in Palm Beach, Florida, where he died in 1964. A year later, to recognize his life's work in the telephone industry, E.C. Blomeyer was inducted into the Independent Telephone Hall of Fame. Additionally, the Blomeyer's were a philanthropic family and shared the benefits of their success. The widow of Edward Charles Blowmeyer, Amma, donated funds to Palm Beach Atlantic College enabling the establishment of the E.C. Blomeyer Library, dedicated on March 9, 1969. The library is now called the Warren Library (dedicated 2007) as a series of donations has enabled Palm Beach Atlantic University to expand since its beginning in 1968. E.C. Blomeyer's legacy carries on as a benefactor of this university, in his writings, photographic record, and contributions to the telephone industry, including that of central Texas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Edward C. Blomeyer photographic collection consists of photo negatives and prints taken by Edward Charles Blomeyer, a pioneer in the telephone industry. His photographic record gives an insight into the early telephone and communications networks of the central Texas area. Additionally, while living in Waco, he photographed the city including popular sites such as Cameron Park and events such as The Texas Cotton Palace. Structures such as many of the city's famous bridges are recorded and events such as auto races are represented. The collection also includes images of early road conditions and scenes around McLennan County, Texas.

Outside of Waco, Blomeyer took images including San Antonio, Austin, and the Texas gulf coast. His vacations were recorded as well, including Yellowstone National Park and Bella Vista, Arkansas. Also photographed are ships, autos, airplanes, people-including family members, and his home state of Missouri.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: E.C. Blomeyer organized the photo negatives and prints in this collection by subject using an index card box with small folders separated by divider tabs. The general arrangement remained intact as when the collection was received. It did require some reconciliation of misfiled items and renaming of subjects/series for better identification purposes. The Edward C. Blomeyer photographic collection is now arranged in eight series: I. Company: Telephone, II. Texas, III. Vacation, IV. People, V. Missouri, VI. Transportation, VII. Agriculture, and VIII. General.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: All requests for copying of materials must be submitted to The Texas Collection in writing. Please use the Request Form for Copying Materials sheet. Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator (s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

userestrict.head: Use/Re-use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

processinfo.p: Described by Geoff Hunt. Released on 2014-01-28.

Archivist''s Notes: In Series four, there is a subseries for E.C. Blomeyer and Family pictures. However, there are more images of them throughout the collection including but not limited to the numerous vacation images, Waco, and central Texas.

did.unittitle: Company: Telephone

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: In 1904, E.C. Blomeyer entered the telephone industry working for the Southeast Missouri Telephone Company, in Charleston, Missouri. The images in this series include industry related subjects beginning in the states of Missouri and Illinois. Blomeyer then moved to Waco, Texas, in 1912, to work for the Brazos Valley Telegraph and Telephone Company, and later The Texas Telephone Company after a large merger of many independent telephone entities.

The merging expanded operations of the Texas Telephone Company to Lorena, Mart, McGregor, Moody, and West, Texas. By 1918, E.C. Blomeyer had become president of the TTC and the company continued to buy out or merge with several other telephone operations around the state. The images in this series help document the work done after these acquisitions. In some cases, telephone poles, lines, and equipment were primitive or outdated for their time, and they are detailed in these photographs.

did.unittitle: Missouri and Illinois

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries of images includes buildings, office spaces, switch board operators, equipment, and people from the Southeast Missouri Telephone Company. Most are believed to be in or around Charleston, Missouri, although some locations include telephone exchanges in Illinois. These images by E.C. Blomeyer date from approximately 1906 to circa 1912.

scopecontent.head: Description of Material
scopecontent.p: This subseries consists of images of telephone company buildings and related subjects in Texas. Examples include the Brazos Valley Telegraph and Telephone Company in Oglesby, Texas Telephone Company in Waco, and company operations in San Antonio. Also included are interior views of telephone buildings with switchboard operators and office spaces.

Telephone Poles, Lines, and Equipment

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries contains rural telephone poles and lines documented by E.C. Blomeyer. They help show the primitive way in which equipment used for telecommunications was constructed in the early days of this industry in McLennan County, Texas, and surrounding counties. Additionally, storage facilities are included showing a detailed look at early telephones and equipment.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries shows operators, switchboards, and telephone related scenes. The locations the images were taken are in Texas, Missouri, and Illinois.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Edward Charles Blomeyer left behind a detailed photographic record of the state during the time he lived in Waco, Texas (1912-1920), after moving from Missouri to work in the telephone business. He photographed Waco extensively, including images of local military facilities, events, parks, rivers, and parades. Around the state, he took pictures on trips to San Antonio, Austin, New Braunfels, Port Arthur, Galveston, and Lake Greenbriar in Tyler. A few of the images pre-date the year E.C. Blomeyer moved to the state, including some of the images of San Antonio which were taken approximately 1906.

He also photographed the railroad that ran through central Texas including the Missouri Kansas and Texas (MKT) and St. Louis Southwestern Railway (Cotton Belt). These show locomotives, carriages, crossings, and tracks. The rural roadways in and around McLennan County are detailed as Blomeyer took pictures of the rough road conditions encountered in his travels by automobile. Also included is a group of pictures of an unidentified Texas oil field.

did.unittitle: Waco

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: E.C. Blomeyer lived in Waco, Texas, from 1912-1920. As well as serving as President of The Texas Telephone Company, he was also an avid photographer. His images shown in this subseries show Waco during an important time in its history as it was experiencing tremendous growth with many changes.

Some images include Rich Field, Camp MacArthur, derailment of Camp MacArthur troop train, Gurley Park auto race, monuments, Texas Cotton Palace Parade, Texas Cotton Palace main building, cotton trade days on the Waco city square, Brazos River, Washington Street Bridge, floods in downtown, and Elm Street.

did.unittitle: Cameron Park, Rivers, and Bridges

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This group of images shows some of Waco's most popular scenic spots such as Cameron Park, located within the city and the Brazos and Bosque Rivers that flow through the park and nearby downtown. The river crossings that span the Brazos such as the Waco Suspension Bridge, Interurban Bridge, and the Washington Street Bridge are shown. Images of the Brazos River at flood as well as low water levels are seen. Elm Street is included as the images show how it was adversely affected when the nearby Brazos River flooded.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files

Derailment of Camp MacArthur Troop Train

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: On June 18, 1918, troop train number 264, carrying soldiers from the 80th Field Artillery, which was posted at Camp MacArthur, left Waco, Texas, traveling eastward on the Cotton Belt rail line, derailed in the nearby town of Selby. The Waco News-Tribune, June 19-20, 1918, states that the accident caused the deaths of 2 troops: Corporals Laurn Harrell and August Handschumacher, Jr. Additionally, about 30 military personnel and 4 employees of the railroad were injured. The wreckage of the derailment is documented by E.C. Blomeyer in this series of photographs.

Texas Cotton Palace and Parade, Cotton Industry

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The photographs in this group demonstrate the importance of the cotton industry in Waco and McLennan County. The cotton yard that was once located in downtown Waco in the area of Second and Jackson through Clay streets is shown stocked with many bales of cotton ready for market.

Waco was home to the Texas Cotton Palace, an annual event that drew tens of thousands of people annually for several years; an image of the main building is shown. Additionally, this series contains images of the annual Cotton Palace Parade making its way on Austin Avenue. Texas Governor Jim Ferguson is photographed participating in this event.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: These vehicles are uniquely decorated for the Texas Cotton Palace Parade. The middle vehicle is advertising Independent Telephone Companies in South and North Texas and the other two the Brazos Valley Telegraph and Telephone Company. This digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-706.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915, in Waco, Texas.

This image was taken in the vicinity of the cotton yard that was located at South Second and Clay Streets, Waco, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-722.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

This digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-708.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915, in Waco, Texas.

The Texas Cotton Palace Parade makes its way westward on Austin Avenue, the Amicable (Alico) Building can be seen in the distance. This digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-502.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

The Texas Cotton Palace Parade makes its way west on Austin Avenue, Waco, Texas. This digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-501.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

This image is of the main building of the Texas Cotton Palace located in Waco, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-689.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

Texas Governor Jim Ferguson is seen here riding in the Texas Cotton Palace parade as his wagon makes its way on Austin Avenue, Waco, Texas. This digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-505.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

This image shows a cotton yard that was located in the area of South Second and Jackson Streets, Waco, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-505.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

This image was taken in the vicinity of the cotton yard that was located near South Second and Clay Streets, Waco, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-504.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

This image was taken in the vicinity of the cotton yard that was located near South Second and Clay Streets, Waco, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-720.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

Texas Governor Jim Ferguson is seen here riding in the Texas Cotton Palace parade as his wagon makes its way on Austin Avenue, Waco, Texas. This digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-504.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915.

The Texas Cotton Palace Parade is shown with what is believed to be troops from the Texas National Guard walking westward on Austin Avenue, Waco, Texas. This digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-692.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1915, in Waco, Texas.

General

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This group of pictures includes scenes of Waco's military bases such as Camp MacArthur and Rich Field. Other images show auto races, street scenes, the Shakespeare monument, and bird's eye views of downtown. Additionally, the remains of the Huaco Clubhouse after a fire destroyed it are included.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: The Shakespeare monument on Riverside Drive (University-Parks) is shown soon after construction. Its plaque reads: "'Immortal Be His Name-Waco Shaksepere [SIC] Club, 1899-1916." Digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-705.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Telephone Building bird's eye view: on the left is St. Mary's Catholic Church and to the right is Sacred Heart Academy on Washington Avenue; Waco High School is seen in the distance. The Texas Telephone Company building's rooftop which gave this vantage point is located at 119 North 9th Street. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-803.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Auto Race: In Waco's Gurley Park, a fifty-mile auto race used to be held. These photographs taken at Gurley are believed to be competing in this particular event. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-725.2.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Camp MacArthur: Pictured are U.S. Army field artillery soldiers at Camp MacArthur training on the range. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-760.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Street Scene: E.C. and Amma Blomeyer go for a drive in their Ford Model-T. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ½ by 3 ½ -inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-695.2.tif, circa 1912.

Street Scene: E.C. Blomeyer hand cranks his Ford Model-T while wife, Amma, looks on. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ½ by 3 ½ -inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-695.3.tif. Date is circa 1912.

Auto Race: In Waco's Gurley Park, a fifty-mile auto race used to be held. These photographs taken at Gurley are believed to be competing in this particular event. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-724.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Rich Field: This photo shows a crashed Army Air Corp bi-plane from Rich Field. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-720.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917

Rich Field: This photo shows an Army Air Corp bi-plane from Rich Field. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-909.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Telephone Building bird's eye view: downtown Waco looking towards the Amicable Building from the Texas Telephone Company's rooftop, the building is located at 119 North 9th Street. Digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-496.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Auto Race: In Waco's Gurley Park, a fifty-mile auto race used to be held. These photographs taken at Gurley are believed to be competing in this particular event. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ½- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-txwaco-725.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Central and South Texas

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries shows images of Texas such as Austin, Galveston, Port Aransas, San Antonio, Waxahachie, Tyler, and New Braunfels. Other scenes show rural gravel roads in or around McLennan County and the rough conditions early motorists faced. Other pictures show examples of the many rail roads and an unidentified oil and natural gas "boomtown."

did.unittitle: Railroad

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series of photographs consists mainly of steam locomotives hauling passengers and freight by the Katy (Missouri, Kansas, and Texas-M.K.& T.) Railroad of Texas. Some images may have been taken in Waco near the Katy depot but most are taken in rural areas in or around McLennan County, Texas.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: A passenger and freight steam locomotive believed to be from the from the Katy (Missouri Kansas and Texas-M.K.&T.) Railroad is shown passing through an unknown rural location. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-879.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Shown in this image is a passenger train powered by 2 steam locomotive of the Katy (Missouri Kansas and Texas-M.K.&T.) Railroad. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-436.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Shown in this image is a passenger train powered by two steam locomotives of the Katy (Missouri Kansas and Texas-M.K.&T.) Railroad. Waco's well-known photographer, Fred Gildersleeve, is shown posing next to the tree on the right of the picture. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-508.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

A steam locomotive of the Katy (Missouri Kansas and Texas-M.K.&T.) Railroad is shown at a crossing. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-438.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

A close-up view of a steam locomotive hauling freight is shown in this photo. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-433.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

A passenger steam train from the Katy (Missouri Kansas and Texas-M.K.&T.) Railroad is shown passing through an unknown rural location. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-440.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, February 24, 1918.

A passenger and freight steam locomotive of the Katy (Missouri Kansas and Texas-M.K.&T.) Railroad passes in or near Waco, Texas. An advertisement for Waco's famous department store, Sanger Brother's, is seen along the line to the left. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-693.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

A steam locomotive with passenger and freights cars passes through one of the many rail lines through McLennan County, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-436.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, May 28, 1917.

A passenger steam train with passengers hanging out of the windows is shown passing through an unknown rural location. This could possibly be a troop train going to or from Camp MacArthur. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-501.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

This image shows a steam passenger locomotive in an unknown location. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ½ by 3 ½ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-688.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1916.

Rural Roadways and Autos

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: E.C. Blomeyer captured several scenes of the roads around Waco, McLennan County, and the central Texas area at a time when they were suited more for wagons than automobiles. He consistently photographed his Ford Model-T along these roads as if to record the adverse conditions he encountered in his travels.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: This scenic view is believed to be in the Texas hill country. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-766.2. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

A rural road scene taken in the central Texas area. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-515.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

This road is in or on the outskirts of the city of Waco. An advertisement for Waco's McLendon Hardware store is seen to the right. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-693.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

E.C. Blomeyer's caption on the back of the printed version of this photograph reads: "A Texas road." The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-802.1.tif. Photo taken circa 1917.

This road is in or on the outskirts of the city of Waco. On the license plate of the Ford Model-T, pictured, is its number, then "WACO." The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-721.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

E.C. Blomeyer's caption on the back of the printed version of this photograph reads: "Panorama-on the road to McGregor [Texas]." The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-789.1.tif. Photo taken circa 1917.

A stop along the road, possibly around the Waco area; the two men are employees of The Texas Telephone Company. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-901.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Fixing a flat tire on a rural Texas road. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4 inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-783.2.tif. Photo taken circa 1917.

This road is believed to be in or around the Waco city limits. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-802.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

A farm scene taken from along the side of a rural Texas road. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-515.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Two girls pick flowers along a rural road side somewhere in central Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-766.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1917.

Cities, Sites, and Coastal Scenes

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This group of images includes some of Texas' most prominent sites such as the State Capitol in Austin, the Alamo in San Antonio, and the Texas gulf coast. Coastal images include the Galveston Causeway, Hotel Galvez, and Galveston Seawall.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: San Antonio: This photograph was taken on the Alamo Plaza, San Antonio, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-759.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Gulf Coast: This photograph was taken in an unknown location on the Gulf Coast of Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-759.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

San Antonio: This image shows the exterior of the Alamo, San Antonio, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-396.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Austin: A bird's eye view of downtown Austin, Texas, showing some of its churches in the distance. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-800.10.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

San Antonio: This image shows the exterior of the Alamo, San Antonio, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-395.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.
San Antonio: The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-397.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Austin: The Texas State Capitol is photographed from Congress Avenue, Austin, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-688.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1916.

Austin: This photograph was taken from the front steps of the Texas State Capitol building in Austin. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-800.08.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Gulf Coast: An unknown man stands outside of the Hotel Galvez, Galveston Island, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-816.11.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

San Antonio: This photograph was taken on the Alamo Plaza, San Antonio, Texas. It shows the Alamo in the distance and just to the right, the Menger Hotel is situated behind the trees and surrounded by vehicles of all types. E.C. Blomeyer took this photograph in about 1906, prior to moving to this state in 1912. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4 ½-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-781.tif.

Gulf Coast: The seawall is seen in front of the Hotel Galvez, Galveston Island, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-922.4.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Gulf Coast: This photograph was taken in an unknown location on the Gulf Coast of Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-785.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Austin: This photograph shows a bird's eye view of Congress Avenue and the Texas State Capitol in Austin. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-794.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

San Antonio: The exterior of the Alamo, San Antonio, Texas. E.C. Blomeyer took this photograph in about 1906, prior to moving to this state in 1912. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4 ½-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-754.2.tif.

Austin: A scenic view of early Austin, Texas, with the Texas State Capitol in the distance. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾-inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-800.09.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Gulf Coast: This photograph shows an early view of the the Galveston Causeway and the original railroad bridge across this span. On the back of the printed version of this photograph, Blomeyer made note of the telephone lines stretching alongside the structures. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-centexsotex-795.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Oil and Natural Gas Field

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This group of photographs shows one of Texas' many booming oil and natural gas fields of the early 20th century. Its location is unknown.

Vacation

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: Ranging from Arkansas to Canada, E.C. Blomeyer and family took many trips that they documented through taking photographs of their favorite scenes, activities, living spaces, and people they knew or met on their journeys.

did.unittitle: Bella Vista, Arkansas

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries shows pictures E.C. Blomeyer took while on vacation at Bella Vista, Benton County, Arkansas. Images are of lakes, wooded areas and trails, water falls, caves, cabins, and various people including family members.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: Unidentified vacationers at Bella Vista, Arkansas, pose with a well-traveled auto. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-948.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

Bella Vista, Arkansas, was a popular vacation spot enjoyed by the Blomeyer family. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-948.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

Colorado: Royal Gorge Route & Pikes Peak

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The printed photographs in this series show the observation tower at the top of Pikes Peak and the cog train rail track that leads to it. Also shown is Royal Gorge, Canon City, and the railroad route that travels through the mountain range.

Vacation: Colorado
Mount Pisgah, North Carolina

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries includes images taken of the trails and views on Mount Pisgah, North Carolina. Most of the images are views taken of the surrounding Appalachian mountain ranges from the mountain top.

Potomac Canal, George Washington's Tomb and Monument

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries includes images of the exterior of George Washington's tomb in Mt. Vernon, Virginia, and a park service employee overseeing it. Another image shows the George Washington Monument in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Scenic views of the Potomac Canal around Maryland and Virginia are included; E.C. Blomeyer is photographed standing on its banks.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: George Washington Monument in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, located on the Court of Honor. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ½ by 4 ½ -inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-950.3.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming

bioghist.p: This group of photographs includes scenes of Yellowstone National park including geyser basins, water falls, gorges, and buffalo.

Niagra Falls

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The Blomeyer family traveled to Niagra Falls, circa 1920. This subseries shows scenes including Honeymoon Bridge, and an early version of the "Maid of the Mist" that still transports passengers close to the falls.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: Edward, Earle, Mary, and Amma Blomeyer pose with the British flag, Niagra Falls, Ontario, Canada. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-893.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

The Honeymoon Bridge connected both sides of Niagra Falls: New York and Ontario, Canada. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-790.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

The "Maid of the Mist" transported visitors to the falls. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-773.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

General

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This group of photographs includes lake scenes, rivers, ponds, creeks, mountains, and wooded areas or forests. It also contains images of bridges, monuments, fountains, and structures including buildings, and cabins. A few images contain a group of Native Americans.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: Native Americans are photographed in an unknown location. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-790.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

Native Americans and a group are photographed canoeing in an unknown location. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-vacat-790.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1920.

People

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The majority of the people in this series are unidentified with the exception of a few including E.C. Blomeyer and his immediate family. Most of the locations include Missouri, Texas, and a few images taken after the Blowmeyer's move to Illinois after 1920.

did.unittitle: E.C. Blomeyer and Family

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries includes images of Edward Charles (E.C.) Blomeyer and his immediate family: wife Amma, daughter Mary, and sons Edward and Earle. Included are candid photos taken in Missouri, Waco, Texas, and Illinois.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: Amma Blomeyer with daughter, Mary, stand along the banks of the Brazos River, Waco, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-cprb-816.9.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1914.
Edward Charles Blowmeyer prepares his camera on one of Cameron Park's bluffs, Waco, Texas, circa 1917. Scanned from a photo print. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-pplblofmly-001.tif.

Pictured near Chicago, Illinois, in 1923, are E.C. Blomeyer, far left, sons Edward and Earle, and an unidentified man. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-pplblofmly-798.1.tif.

Edward and Earle Blomeyer stand with their father's Ford Model-T. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾ inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-897.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1918.

Missouri

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: The photos in the series include the aftermath of a flood and subsequent damage. Other images show general street scenes in rural areas and towns. Another group of photos is of the John Robinson Circus in an unknown town. Shown is its arrival by train followed by a circus parade. Other images show lakes, rivers, and railroad tracks.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: Circus train: The John Robinson Circus comes to an unidentified Missouri town by rail. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-755.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Flood Scene: A neighboring flooded field poses a potential threat to the property seen in this picture. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-910.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Attendees are seen entering the John Robinson Circus. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-784.4.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Circus Parade: Performers of the John Robinson Circus take part in a parade in a Missouri town. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-755.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Circus Parade: Elephants of the John Robinson Circus march down the street of a Missouri town. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-754.3.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Circus Parade: A John Robinson Circus parade. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-755.4.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Flood Scene: This image shows a group of people navigating on a flooded river. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-793.1.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Circus Parade: Camels of the John Robinson Circus march down the street of a Missouri town. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-754.4.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

In this unidentified industrial facility, the large belt driven fly-wheel was used as a power source for machinery or equipment of equal proportions. The digital image is from a scan of a 4 by 3 ¼- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-missouri-753.2.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1906

Transportation

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series contains images of aircraft, automobiles, street cars, wagons or carriages, and watercraft including steamships, river boats, sailboats, and ferries. Several examples of early steam powered water vessels are represented. One better known example is a photograph of the passenger steamship "Eastland," included in this collection.

bibref.extref: Young, David, "The Eastland disaster: A summer excursion turns into the worst accident in the annals of Great Lakes shipping." Chicago Tribune (Chicago, Ill), undated. Accessed December 28, 2013.

relatedmaterial.head: Collection Files
relatedmaterial.archref: Watercraft: The passenger steam ship "Eastland" is shown in this image. On July 24, 1915, while docked in Chicago, Illinois, for departure on a cruise to Michigan City, Indiana, it rolled over onto its side causing passengers to be thrown into the water. This tipping or listing of the vessel began after the 2,573 passengers had boarded. This accident claimed the lives of 844 men, women, and children. It is reported the incident caused the largest number of deaths in any single event in the continental U.S. in the twentieth century. Digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-792.1.tif. The picture was taken circa 1906 by E.C. Blomeyer when the vessel was operated

Watercraft: The riverboat "Grey Eagle" in Missouri. Its destination plaques read: "St. Louis-Cape Girardeau." Digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-779.tif. Photo taken by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Watercraft: People wait or watch a large steamship off in the distance. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-786.3.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912.

Watercraft: A river ferry carries passengers in this scene most likely taken somewhere in Missouri. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-947.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Watercraft: Steamship "Quantico" with tender at an unidentified port. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-817.2.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910

Autos: An unknown group pile into an auto for a ride. The digital image is from a scan of a 6 by 3 ¾- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-764.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1912

This scene shows carriages and wagons at an event taken most likely in Missouri. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-913.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1906

Aircraft: A Wright Brothers Model B is shown in an unspecified location, possibly San Antonio, Texas. Notice the two clamps repairing the lower left wing tip's edge. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-499.3.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Watercraft: The steamship "Chequamegon," of the Pabst Brewing Company's White Fish Bay Resort. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-778.2.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1906

Aircraft: A Wright Brothers Model B is shown in an unspecified location, possibly San Antonio, Texas. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-499.2.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Watercraft: An empty river ferry and tender stand empty in this scene most likely in Missouri. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-947.2.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Watercraft: A large unidentified steamship fills the air as it approaches. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-947.3.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Autos: This early bus photograph was taken in an unknown location. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-922.2.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910.

Watercraft: Steam powered river boats line up at an unidentified location. The digital image is from a scan of a 1 ¾ by 2 ¾- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-817.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910

Autos: This large automobile was photographed in Misssouri. The digital image is from a scan of a 3 ¼ by 4- inch, cellulose nitrate negative. Digital ID: tx-phoarch-blomeyer_3886-transp-783.1.tif. Photo by E.C. Blomeyer, circa 1910

Agriculture

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This subseries contains images of ranching and crop-raising. Included are livestock such as cattle, goats, pigs, and chickens. The crop scenes show fields and an early water irrigation system. Locations are not certain, but it is believed that most are of Texas with some images taken in Missouri.

bioghist.head: Biography/Profile
bioghist.p: This series of photographs consists of several small combined groups such as unidentified homes, rugs, photos taken for publications, and animals such as birds and horn toads. The publication photographs were sent to Popular Mechanics Magazine, for stories written about filing photographic negatives, organizing hand tools, and home improvement.

bibref.extref: Blomeyer, Edward Charles. "Filing Prints and Negatives in Card Cabinet." Popular Mechanics Magazine, January 1919.
